text: I think the biggest thing when people get involved with options is they pay way too much attention to the individual strategies. Like I'm going to do a broken wing condor on the stock. And I'm not saying those things are not important. Like we just discussed, when you're trying to get the variance premium, the exact structure of your trade now has become much more important than it used to be. So getting the structure of your trade is correct, is a good thing. But the important thing, the initial thing is to know where your edge is coming from. Actually, why do I have a statistical advantage here over the market? Like if you're a stock trader, the first thing you think about isn't portfolio composition. The first thing you think about is what stock should I buy? And then how does it fit into the rest of my portfolio? And options traders tend to get that the wrong way around. They think about the structure of the trade. And if you listen to CNBC or watch something like that, you'll see that there's a lot of structure. There's a lot of money in the stock market. So you're going to be able to buy some garbage on YouTube or whatever. That's what they're always talking about. It's like, you can sell this iron condor and you can make this amount of money 90% of the time. Incidentally, the iron condor is a very, very dangerous trade, but not for the reasons people might think it is. The big problem with that is when you do trades, you get feedback. As I said before, you eventually get feedback from your P&L. The problem with the iron condor is you're going to have an awful lot of winners and not very many losers. losers so it makes doing statistics on it very difficult because the only statistic that matters is your average and you don't really see the average with a very very skewed payout trade like that you see the mode and the mode is unbelievably good trades like that are difficult for that reason even if it works and the iron Condor because of the variance premium usually has Edge but you're not going to know how much Edge because of that problem so you don't have to have a size of the trade but anyway if you're looking at CNBC the things they're talking about on a trade are like let's do this call spread because it has this profit of winning sorry this chance of winning and it can make this profit they're not talking about why and they're not talking about the price of the call spread people don't pay enough attention to the price of these options as the price of getting into the bet everyone's always complaining you know I bought a call the market went up I didn't make any money well that's because you paid the wrong damn price for the call I mean you can talk about Vega and Delta and Gamma and all these things and now they're and they're important but they're ways of translating Market movement into dollars they're like a P&L attribution scheme you don't make money because of your Delta or your Gamma or your Theta you make money because the market moves or the market didn't and I think people kind of get all that kind of confused and the most important thing to do when you do a trade is look for your Edge and then because of that Edge how big do I do that trade and how does it fit into the rest of my portfolio like I think the most important thing with investing in any situation is your P&L number that's your Edge the next most important thing is the smoothness of your P&L and that's kind of your historical risk and finally how does all that what in one trade fit into my whole portfolio of trades and options traders on the retail side at least tend to get that completely backwards and I don't think there's much difference between the average buy side and the retail in terms of how they think
